title-group.article-title: Effects of Find Thirty every day®
title-group.subtitle: Cross-Sectional Findings From a Western Australian Population-Wide Mass Media Campaign, 2008-2010

article-meta.aff: 1University of Western Australia, Perth, Western Australia, Australia
2University of Sydney, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia
3Heart Foundation (WA Division), Subiaco, Western Australia, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Justine E. Leavy, School of Population Health, University of Western Australia, Crawley, Perth, Western Australia 6009, Australia. Email: justine.leavy@uwa.edu.au

abstract.p: Background. Internationally, over the last four decades large-scale mass media campaigns have been delivered to promote physical activity and its associated health benefits. In 2002-2005, the first Western Australian statewide adult physical activity campaign Find Thirty. It’s Not a Big Exercise was launched. In 2007, a new iteration of the campaign was proposed with new objectives, executions, and tag line Find Thirty every day®. Purpose. This article reports on the population-level effects of the Find Thirty every day® campaign from 2008 to 2010, with a focus on changes in awareness, intention, and physical activity. Methods. Evaluation of the campaign involved pre- and posttest serial cross-sectional surveys. Baseline data were collected in May 2008, and subsequent surveys in 2009 and 2010. Samples sizes were as follows: baseline (n = 972), first follow-up (n = 938), and second follow-up (n = 937). Data were derived from self-reported responses to a random-sample computer-assisted telephone interview. Results. Total awareness increased from 30.4% at baseline to 48.5% at second follow-up. Total awareness was higher in women and low socioeconomic status adults. Intention was 21.0%, double that reported at baseline. There were positive significant changes from baseline to first follow-up across all four categories: walking, moderate, vigorous, and total physical activity. There also were positive significant changes for self-reported walking from baseline to second follow-up. Conclusion. Find Thirty every day® resulted in an increase in awareness, intention, walking, vigorous intensity, and total level of physical activity in priority target groups. Campaign effects should be further examined by subgroups to identify the most receptive population segments.

body.p: Regular moderate-intensity physical activity has well-established health benefits (Bauman, 2004; Kruk, 2007; Penedo & Dahn, 2005; Qin, Knol, Corpeleijn, & Stolk, 2010; Teychenne, Ball, & Salmon, 2010; Warburton, Nicol, & Bredin, 2006). Over the last four decades, large-scale mass media campaigns have been used to promote physical activity and its associated health benefits. To promote participation, a range of physical activity health messages have been delivered, typically via combinations of television, radio, and print media (Abroms & Maibach, 2008). Despite these efforts, many adults in developed countries still fail to achieve the level of physical activity participation required for good health (Biddle & Mutrie, 2008; Haskell et al., 2007; Smith & Bird, 2004).

In Australia, efforts to increase physical activity commenced 35 years ago with the Life. Be In It campaign (Life. Be In It, 2011). In the early 1990s, national mass media campaigns conducted by the National Heart Foundation included Exercise: Make It Part Of Your Day, aimed at all Australians aged 15 years and older (Booth, Bauman, Oldenburg, Owen, & Magnus, 1992). Exercise: Take Another Step built on the earlier campaign and reemphasized walking (Owen, Bauman, Booth, Oldenburg, & Magnus, 1995). In 1998, Exercise: You Only Have To Take It Regularly, Not Seriously was delivered in New South Wales to adults who were motivated but insufficiently active (Bauman, Bellew, Owen, & Vita, 2001).

Between 2002 and 2005, the first Western Australian statewide physical activity campaign Find Thirty. It’s Not a Big Exercise was delivered by the Health Department of Western Australia. The campaign aimed to increase the number of Western Australians who were sufficiently active for good health. By 2006, population data showed less than two thirds of West Australian adults (59%) were sufficiently active for good health, thus providing a rationale for continuing efforts using mass-reach campaigns. In 2007, the second phase of the mass media campaign was proposed, which extended the original Find Thirty campaign with a new focus, objectives, and execution. Using the new tag line Find Thirty every day®, the 2008-2010 population-wide mass media campaign aimed to promote physical, mental, and social health benefits of regular physical activity.

A recent review of the effectiveness of mass media campaigns designed to change health behavior highlighted the importance of using well-defined messages delivered to large target audiences over time, at a low cost (Wakefield, Loken, & Hornik, 2010). Despite a recent increase in physical activity mass media campaigns, comprehensive evaluation of campaign effects have been modest (Bauman & Chau, 2009; Finlay & Faulkner, 2005; Kahn et al., 2002; Leavy, Bull, Rosenberg, & Bauman, 2011). Between 2002 and 2007, the original Find thirty. It’s Not a Big Exercise campaign evaluation comprised a series of small-scale tracking surveys with no baseline data collection. The new Find Thirty every day® campaign evaluation used a serial cross-sectional design consisting of baseline and two follow-ups. In addition, the Find Thirty every day® evaluation included a cohort study of a subset of the participants for future analysis.

This article reports on the population-level effects of Find Thirty every day®, a serial mass media campaign conducted between 2008 to 2010, with a specific focus on changes in awareness, intention, and physical activity in the repeat cross-sectional population samples.

sec.title: Campaign Theory and Development
sec.p: The development of the Find Thirty every day® campaign was undertaken by the National Heart Foundation of Australia. This second phase of the campaign was underpinned by social cognitive theory (SCT), which highlights the dynamic interactions between behavior, the environment, and personal factors. Specifically, SCT was selected for this campaign for its focus on outcome expectancies, self-efficacy, perceptions of others, and the environment (Bandura, 1977). Outcome expectancies are the values that a person places on a particular outcome and were relevant to the Find Thirty every day® message framing, for example, “Find time to talk,” “Finding a way to fit into last year’s jeans,” and “Finding better health” were positive expectancies designed to promote physical activity and identify motivators. Campaign messages overtly targeted personal beliefs. Self-efficacy is the confidence individuals have in their ability to be physically active under a number of circumstances (Marcus, Bock, et al., 1998). Self-efficacy was depicted through a range of everyday activities that an individual could easily fit into their day. The influence of the social and physical environment were incorporated through the portrayal of achievable, group physical activities in a range of community-based settings, for example, “couples dancing in a community hall” and “swimming at a local pool.”

A 10-stage formative process informed the media campaign creative and the development of the message, theme, and images for the television advertisements (Shilton & Maitland, 2009). Key stages included a review of evidence and development and pretesting of creative propositions and concepts by an external advertising agency. Pretesting revealed confusion around what counted as physical activity; how often adults should “Find Thirty”; the importance of social and mental health benefits; and a preference for achievable, accessible activities. Campaign messages were refined based on these findings, and the final advertising concept cast “real people” not actors to convey “finding thirty” as achievable rather than aspirational.

The mass media component of the campaign included seven waves of television media commencing in May 2008 and finishing in March 2010 (see Figure 1). The television commercials targeted all Western Australians aged 20 to 54 years with three 30-second advertisements and four 15-second advertisements. The commercials were shown on metropolitan and regional commercial stations, and the three 30-second advertisements featured a montage of scenarios highlighting a physical activity benefit. These included incidental and everyday physical activities, parents playing with children, adults walking for recreation and transport, dancing or cycling, and active domestic tasks such as raking leaves (Figure 2). The final voice over for each advertisement was “You’ll find all kinds of rewards when you find 30 minutes physical activity every day.” The television campaign was also supported by radio and print advertising, billboards, website and online resources, and a range of activities that targeted communities and the workplace (Figure 2).

caption.p: Find Thirty every day® campaign media waves, evaluation design and TARPS.
a. In metropolitan Western Australia—Target Audience Rating points (TARPs).
Find Thirty every day® campaign resource descriptors.

sec.p: Campaign diagnostics were collected only for metropolitan television using Target Audience Rating Points (TARPs). These are a marketing measure representing an estimate of the population reach of the target or priority group within the total audience of a specific TV channel or program reached by an advertisement (see Figure 1). The overall campaign design, development, and implementation (without evaluation costs) had an approximate total budget of $1.8 million Australian Dollars over 2.5 years.

sec.title: Research Design
sec.p: The evaluation of the campaign involved pre- and postcampaign cross-sectional surveys (see Figure 2). Baseline data were collected in May 2008 (referred to as XS1) and subsequent surveys in March-April 2009 (post–media Wave 3, referred to as XS2), and February-March 2010 (post–media Wave 7, referred to as XS3).

sec.title: Survey Participants
sec.p: All participants were randomly selected from the 2006 Western Australian electronic telephone directory of residential phone numbers. Participants were recruited from within households, with the adults whose birthday was next invited to participate in the survey. Up to 10 callbacks were made to each household. The sampling protocol also required equal proportions of men and women, and a quarter to be from regional Western Australia. Inclusion criteria were English speaking, aged between 20 and 54 years, and those who did not suffer from a disease or disability that would prevent them from doing moderate physical activity. The overall total sample size was n = 3,006, and the overall response rates achieved (completed surveys divided by the eligible contacts plus noncontacts after 10 attempts) were 77%, 79%, and 89% for baseline, first follow-up, and second follow-up, respectively. Data were cleaned and participants with one or multiple missing variables were removed, resulting in a final useable sample of 2,847. Samples sizes were as follows: baseline data (XS1, n = 972), first follow-up (XS2, n = 938), and second follow-up (XS3, n = 937).

sec.title: Survey Measures
sec.p: Data were derived from self-reported responses to a random-sample Computer Assisted Telephone Interview. The 75-item survey incorporated items from a previous tracking survey (TNS Social Research, 2005) plus new items. The study protocol was approved by the Human Ethics Research Review Panel at the University of Western Australia.

Awareness of the Find Thirty every day® TV campaign was assessed by a combination of prompted recall (“In the last 3 months, do you remember seeing any TV ads about physical activity or exercise?”) and prompted recognition (“Have you seen the following TV ads?” . . . Read advert description). Prompted recall is recorded as an open-ended verbatim response that is coded as “yes” for recalling Find Thirty every day® TV advertisements or “no” for recall unrelated to the advertisement. Prompted recognition is asked as a closed-ended question and respondents indicate “yes” or “no” if they recognized the campaign advertisement based on the read descriptions of the advertisements. Campaign awareness (“total awareness”) was calculated as the total number of individuals who either recall the advertisement or recognize it through prompting (i.e., “prompted recall” + “prompted recognition”). Respondents “aware” of the campaign were then asked what they understood the message to mean, and respondents who understood the message were asked how personally “acceptable” (acceptance) they found it and whether they intended to do something in response to the message.

Physical activity was assessed using the Active Australia questions that have been validated and used in national and state-based physical activity population surveys (Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, 2003; Brown, Bauman, Chey, Trost, & Mummery, 2004; Brown, Trost, Bauman, Mummery, & Owen, 2004). They have also been used extensively in interventions and in mass media campaign evaluation (Bauman, Bellew, et al., 2001; Bauman, Ford, & Armstrong, 2001). Self-reported physical activity behavior is a complex behavior to assess and known to be subject to measurement error due to overreporting (Milligan, McCormack, & Rosenberg, 2007). Thus, consistent with previous research, in the Find Thirty campaign analysis, physical activity was truncated at 14 hours (or 840 minutes) for each category of physical activity (i.e., walking, moderate-intensity physical activity, and vigorous-intensity physical activity). This method of truncation is consistent with the 1999, 2002, and 2006 Western Australian surveys (Bull, Milligan, Rosenberg, & MacGowan, 2001) and National Active Australia recommendations (Armstrong, Bauman, & Davies, 2000). Usual scoring rules were applied to the data (Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, 2003; Milligan et al., 2007). Demographic variables included gender, age, location (by postcode), socioeconomic status (SES; 2006 Western Australian census population SEIFA disadvantage score tertile cutoffs were used to group respondents into low, medium, and high SES groups), education, and height and weight were also collected. Body mass index (BMI) was calculated using height and weight and the cutoffs: underweight <18.5, normal 18.5 to 24.9, overweight 25 to 29.9, and obese >30. Because of small numbers in the underweight category (n = 52), it was combined with the normal category to form one category, and overweight and obese were combined to form the other category reported in the analyses as either “Underweight/normal” or “Overweight/obese.”

sec.title: Analysis
sec.p: Descriptive statistics summarized the demographic characteristics of respondents in each survey. Data were weighted by age, gender, and geographical location to the 2006 Western Australian Census data. Associations between the demographic characteristics, awareness, and intention were determined by calculating bivariate Pearson chi-square tests. Ranked data were compared using the nonparametric Kruskal–Wallis test for median physical activity time to overcome skewness of the data. Approximate effect size statistics (r) were calculated for those results that were statistically significant in the Kruskal–Wallis test using the criteria of .1 = small effect, .3 = medium effect, .5 = large effect. Forced entry logistic regression was used to calculate odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals for the dichotomous outcomes: awareness (0 = not aware, 1 = aware), intention (0 = no intention, 1 = intention), and physical activity level (0 = inactive/insufficient, 1 = sufficiently active for health). The dependent variables were adjusted for the covariates age, location, and SES. Interaction terms between time and physical activity were included in Model 1. Analyses were conducted using SPSS version 17.0 (IBM SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL) and p values <.05 were considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Demographics
sec.p: Unweighted demographic data and other sample characteristics are shown in Table 1. The samples consisted of approximately equal proportions of men and women, with three quarters of each sample residing in metropolitan Perth across the three time points. There were differences in the age structure and household income with slightly more respondents aged 46 to 54 at XS3. A greater proportion of respondents at XS3 had a combined income of >$100,001 compared with respondents at XS1 and XS2. At each time point, most of the respondents were in full-time paid employment, and at all three time points, more than one third of respondents were tertiary educated. More than half of the respondents at each time point were overweight/obese (BMI = 25 to >30; 54.9%, 53.5%, and 60.3%, respectively).

caption.p: Demographics, Total Awareness, and Intention of the Cross-Sectional Samples (XS1-XS3).

fn.p: Note. Bivariate contingency table Pearson chi-square test at p value < .05.

Denotes a statistically significant difference from XS1 to XS3, p < .05. **Denotes a statistically significant difference from XS1 to XS2, p < .05. ***Denotes a statistically significant difference from XS2 to XS3, p < .05.

sec.title: Campaign Awareness and Intention
sec.p: Table 1 reports total awareness of the television campaign and intention achieved overall and within subgroups. Total awareness increased from 30.4% at XS1 to 45.1% at XS2 and was 48.5% at XS3. Both follow-up measures significantly increased from baseline. Awareness was significantly different between XS1 and XS3 across all subgroups. Notably, total awareness was higher in women than in men at all three time points (32.0% vs. 28.9% at XS1; 51.4% vs. at 42.1% XS2; 50.9% vs. 46.1% at XS3) and total awareness was higher in low socioeconomic areas at XS2 (51.4%) and XS3 (51.5%) compared with medium and high socioeconomic areas (see Table 1).

At XS3, overall intention was 21.0%, twice that reported at XS1. Intention was significantly different between XS1 and XS3 across all the subgroups presented in Table 1, except those who had achieved a university education. The proportion of those who intended to be physically active increased significantly from XS2 to XS3 in two subgroups, income “refused” and insufficiently active, and decreased, significantly, in the subgroup sufficiently active.

Table 2 reports prompted recall, prompted recognition, and awareness of the television commercials and the Find Thirty slogan. At XS3 prompted recall was three times the proportion reported at XS1 (20.9% vs. 6.9%, respectively). In addition, prompted recognition of the Find Thirty slogan reached 87.4% at XS3, which was significantly higher than at XS2 (83.8%; Table 2). Prompted recognition of the campaign slogan was not measured at XS1.

caption.p: Overall Awareness of the Find Thirty every day® Television Campaign.

tr.td: Prompted recall of Find Thirty every day®
Prompted recognition of Find Thirty every day®
Total awareness of Find Thirty every day®
Prompted recognition of Find Thirty slogan

sec.title: Self-Reported Walking, Vigorous, and Total Physical Activity: Continuous Measures
sec.p: Table 3 presents the effects of the intervention on self-reported physical activity time. When comparing median minutes from XS1 to XS2, significant increases were seen across three categories: “Total walking per week” median increase of 30 minutes per week (p = .047); “Total vigorous physical activity per week” median increase of 20 minutes per week (p = .022); and “Total physical activity per week” median increase of 50 minutes per week (p = .004). Only one significant change was seen between XS2 and XS3, namely, in “Total walking per week” (p = .034). “Total moderate physical activity per week” remained unchanged at 0 minutes for all three time points.

caption.p: Median Minutes of “Total Walking,” “Total Moderate Physical Activity,” “Total Vigorous Physical Activity,” and “Total Physical Activity” by Subgroups XS1-XS3.

fn.p: Note. IQR = interquartile range; PA = physical activity; BMI = body mass index. Kruskal–Wallis test asymp. sig. for median p value <.05.

fn.label: a
fn.p: The calculation of Total Physical Activity includes total walking, moderate-intensity, and vigorous intensity physical activity per week.

Denotes a statistically significant difference from XS1 to XS3, p < .05. **Denotes a statistically significant difference from XS1 to XS2, p < .05. ***Denotes a statistically significant difference from XS2 to XS3, p < .05.

sec.p: In subgroup analyses, significant increases were seen among women at XS1 and XS2 for “vigorous physical activity” and “total physical activity” and between men for walking only. “Total physical activity” significantly increased, between XS1 and XS2, for people living in the metropolitan area, aged 35 to 45 years, among university-educated respondents, and those classified as underweight/normal BMI.

sec.title: Awareness, Intention, and Physical Activity Level: Dichotomous Analyses
sec.p: Table 4 shows the impact of the campaign on awareness, intention, and total physical activity. There was an almost twofold significant increase in awareness at XS2 compared with XS1 and a 2.22 increase at XS3 compared with XS1. Women (adjusted odds ratio [AOR] = 1.30, 95% confidence interval [CI]= 1.12-1.53) and those who were sufficiently active (AOR = 1.27, 95% CI = 1.08-1.50) were more likely to be aware of the campaign (Model 1, Table 3). Intention, after adjustment, showed a twofold increase at XS2 and almost 2.5 times increase at XS3 (Model 2, Table 3). There was an increase in physical activity for adults at XS3 compared with XS1 (AOR = 1.22, 95% CI = 1.01-1.48). Those who had achieved a higher school certificate (AOR = 1.27, 95% CI = 1.04-1.54) or a university education (AOR = 1.79, 95% CI = 1.54-2.33) also showed a difference in physical activity for adults. Physical activity was lower among those classified as overweight/obese adults compared with those classified as underweight/normal adults (AOR = 0.74, 95% CI = 0.63-0.88; Model 3, Table 3) All these results were significant at the p <.05 level.

caption.p: Adjusted Odds Ratio for Awareness, Intention, and Physical Activity by Subgroups (N = 2,847).

fn.p: Note. AOR = adjusted odds ratio; CI = confidence interval; BMI = body mass index; SES = socioeconomic status.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Adjusted for age, location, and SES.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Find Thirty every day® forms Phase 2 of a serial mass media campaign that extended the previous Find Thirty. It’s Not a Big Exercise campaign with a new focus, objectives, and execution to promote physical, mental, and social health benefits of regular physical activity among Western Australian adults. The campaign achieved almost 50% awareness after 2 years, and when prompted, almost 9 out of 10 people recalled the campaign slogan, reinforcing the importance of a sustained Find Thirty campaign brand over time. The 30% observed campaign awareness at baseline appeared to be the legacy of residual campaign awareness, that is, we have some carryover recall and/or recognition of the original Find Thirty. It’s Not a Big Exercise campaign, which had been to air as recently as November 2007, just 6 months prior to the second phase Find Thirty every day® campaign. In today’s world, we are working in an increasingly campaign-cluttered environment. Finding a population that has not been previously exposed to a similar campaign, while not impossible, is not practically meaningful—because most target audiences, at least in the developed countries, have already been exposed to a variety of campaigns. Despite this, the evaluation of Find Thirty every day® reported here still showed some effects, building on the baseline levels and occurring after the previous waves of Find Thirty mass media. In addition, our findings suggest that the campaign resonated with women more than men and reached the priority group of low-SES adults. These positive results show continuous building on the Find Thirty brand.

A critical determinant of campaign effectiveness is campaign message exposure, which includes both “dose,” a quantified measure of the campaign message delivered to the population (Cavill & Bauman, 2004), and “reach,” the proportion of the population exposed to the message (Salmon & Atkin, 2003). Find Thirty every day® delivery was concentrated mostly in 2 to 3 week blocks of television, radio, and print advertisements (see Figure 1) and was scheduled to avoid overlap with other campaigns and with extended vacation periods. TARPs were purchased in the highest performing commercial television shows for the age-group 25 to 54 years. Of note, the total TARPs purchased for the previous campaign were slightly greater and spread over fewer TV channels, partly due to an increase in TARP price and the changing television landscape (increase from 5 to 11 free to air television stations during the campaign period). The literature suggests that mass media campaigns may be less effective if message dose and reach is limited with the target audience (Hornik, 2002; Reger-Nash et al., 2005). The media purchased was concentrated in discrete, specific time-limited blocks of exposure and specifically selected to increase awareness in priority groups. Accordingly, this may account for higher awareness by women and those in low-SES groups. The type of media, its dose, and reach (i.e., the media mix) all have the potential to affect campaign awareness; however, getting maximum exposure needs to be carefully orchestrated to include multiple channels and sufficient duration or a subgroup as the target population for which a specific level of exposure is sought (Hornik, 2002). These results suggest the media mix strategy may have contributed to the observed Find Thirty every day® campaign effects. Careful planning with input from the campaign team, the commercial advertising agency, and researchers to maximize dose and reach produced a positive result for priority groups.

Increased awareness is an important proximal impact measure of mass media campaigns and is usually assessed through measures of campaign recall, recognition, and understanding the campaign message (Bauman et al., 2003; Cavill & Bauman, 2004). Awareness levels achieved in this campaign increased across the surveys (Leavy, Barnes, & Maitland, 2010). Push Play in New Zealand, a 9-year multiphase physical activity mass media campaign, achieved awareness levels of 65.4%, 59.6%, 57.2% in 2000, 2004, and 2006 (Bauman & Chau, 2009). The Find Thirty every day® results are also consistent with recent reviews of physical activity mass media campaigns (Cavill & Bauman, 2004; Leavy et al., 2011; Wakefield et al., 2010).

Of particular interest is the differential impact on awareness achieved by this campaign; specifically, we found higher awareness in women and in the low-SES group. Higher awareness of physical activity campaign messages by women have been reported in studies in Australia (Brown, Mummery, Eakin, & Schofield, 2006), Europe, (De Cocker, De Bourdeaudhuij, Brown, & Cardon, 2007), and the United States (Buchthal et al., 2011; Craig, Bauman, Gauvin, Robertson, & Murumets, 2009) and in low income, ethnic groups in the United States (Buchthal et al., 2011). This is a positive finding for mass reach campaigns, consistent with the literature (Buchthal et al., 2011; Craig et al., 2009; Spence et al., 2009; Vallone, Allen, & Xiao, 2009). However, our low-SES finding contrasts with the “knowledge gap” hypothesis literature that suggests that the higher an individual’s education, the higher the motivation to attend to and comply with health messages (Droomers, Schrijvers, van de Mheen, & Mackenbach, 1998; Spence et al., 2009; Vallone et al., 2009). Differential awareness in this campaign may in part be explained by (a) the inclusion of priority groups in the formative research that informed the campaign and more likely (b) the changing landscape of television in Western Australia over the past 3 years. The TV advertisements were also embedded in programming that reached the target audience. Of note, the montage of TV commercials featured more women, including “a group of ladies walking,” a “woman riding her bike,” another featured “a woman raking leaves,” and a “female office worker in jogging shoes.” In addition, the 80 nonprofessional actors were “real people” in the TV commercials. This campaign deliberately selected a variety of “body shapes and sizes” including overweight adults to model the messages. The campaign promoted low-cost, easily accessible physical activities such as “children playing football with their father in the park,” “walking the dog,” and “swimming at a local pool.” Therefore, this campaign may have resonated more with women and low-SES groups. Nonselective mainstream TV advertising may be more effective at reaching this group (Buchthal et al., 2011). Future considerations for mass media campaign planners and evaluators should be greater awareness of TV viewing and recording habits and the potential positive and negative impact this may have on campaign differential awareness. To date, this has not been researched in any detail.

The ultimate goal of mass media campaigns is to encourage and sustain positive behavior change. Significant increases in all three categories of self-reported walking, vigorous, and total physical activity were reported in this campaign. Internationally, only a few physical activity campaigns have reported significant sustained changes in physical activity behavior (Leavy et al., 2011). However, of those that have, 10 000 Steps Ghent (Belgium) found significant increases in mean steps/day (De Cocker et al., 2007), Wheeling Walks, WV Walks, and BC Walks (the United States) all reported significant increases in walking (Reger-Nash et al., 2005; Reger-Nash et al., 2006; Reger-Nash et al., 2008). In addition, Agita São Paulo (Brazil) reported significant increases in individuals’ physical activity (Matsudo et al., 2010). Nevertheless, direct comparisons between other campaigns and Find Thirty every day® are difficult; they all vary in evaluation design, sample size, duration, physical activity measurement, and outcome reported. In contrast, New Zealand’s Push Play was a more similar campaign in terms of focus and evaluation design, and yet it found no initial changes in physical activity behavior.

By subgroups, our findings show women made significant gains in self-reported vigorous physical activity and total physical activity between XS1 to XS2 and those who were university educated made significant gains in total physical activity between XS1 and XS3. This is consistent with the literature that suggests women are receptive to messages regarding walking (Craig, Cragg, Tudor-Locke, & Bauman, 2006), are “early adopters” of behavior change (Brown et al., 2006; Craig et al., 2006), and walking is the most common type of physical activity (Brownson et al., 2000; Saelens, Sallis, & Frank, 2003). Our results show a similar trend to the established literature with low-SES groups and those with less education achieving insufficient physical activity to gain health benefits (Armstrong et al., 2000; Buchthal et al., 2011; Giles-Corti & Donovan, 2002b). This raises the issue of higher educated and higher SES groups having greater potential to gain skills and access resources and facilities such as walk paths and cycle ways to be physically active (Droomers et al., 1998; Giles-Corti & Donovan, 2002a, 2002b; Marcus, Owen, Forsyth, Cavill, & Fridinger, 1998; Mutrie & Hannah, 2004; Wendel-Vos, Droomers, Kremers, Brug, & Van Lenthe, 2007). Furthermore, those of low SES may have less opportunity and face greater barriers to increase their physical activity (Giles-Corti & Donovan, 2002a, 2002b). In addition, recent findings reinforce that climate is an important factor for certain population subgroups, especially those who are less active who perceive it as a barrier (Badland, Christian, Giles-Corti, & Knuiman, 2011). Our data were collected at the end of summer, typically a warm-hot period of time in Western Australia, which may partly explain decreases in walking in the insufficiently active and warrants further investigation. Opportunities to access enablers to action, such as social and environmental supports for physical activity promotion, especially in low-SES groups, are an important area for continued research (Giles-Corti & Donovan, 2002b; Wendel-Vos et al., 2007).

The literature acknowledges the difficulty of achieving an increase in population levels of physical activity using mass media alone (Cavill & Bauman, 2004; Kahn et al., 2002; Leavy et al., 2011; Wakefield et al., 2010), and there is a need for a combination of social, environmental, and policy supports in place (Bauman et al., 2003; Brown et al., 2006; Reger-Nash et al., 2005). Three previously mentioned U.S. community-wide walking interventions (Wheeling Walks [WW], WV Walks, and BC Walks) all used a combination of media-relations and community-wide activities and environmental changes and instigated local taskforces or coalitions of stakeholders to support the campaigns (Reger-Nash et al., 2005; Reger-Nash, et al., 2006; Reger-Nash, et al., 2008). 10 000 Steps Rockhampton Australia, a community-wide intervention, used mass media, marketing strategies, and engaged general practitioners (GPs) to promote physical activity and worked with local councils to erect 10 000 Steps signage and repair key footpaths (Brown et al., 2006). Similarly, 10 000 Steps Ghent, Belgium, erected street signage to show the number of steps to get to and from places and installed walking circuits in two local town parks (De Cocker et al., 2007). Agita São Paulo (Brazil) combined extensive free media, with mega-events and partnerships with local organizations (Matsudo et al., 2010). Activate Omaha (the United States) used a social marketing approach that resulted in several policy changes related to bike and pedestrian access over a 5-year period and reported infrastructure and behavior changes. In this campaign, Find Thirty every day®, the primary strategy adopted was mass media with limited additional community-wide programs; some sponsorship of sports, art, and racing events; some collaboration to promote the annual Walk Week; and point-of-decision prompts, for example, a poster placed near lifts and elevators suggesting “Take the stairs instead” (Figure 2). Accordingly, future campaigns in Western Australia need to incorporate more social marketing strategies rather than rely on mass media alone. This could include walking groups, community events in regional and metropolitan regions, and the implementation and promotion of environmental supports such as dual access walking and cycling paths and attractive, well-equipped recreational parks together with continued advocacy for policy change.

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations
sec.p: This research has a number of design and sampling methods strengths. First, response rates were high for all three time points because up to 10 callbacks were made to recruit study participants. Using three time points and substantial samples in each survey was a strength. However, there were several measurement limitations. Self-reported measures are susceptible to socially desirable responses. Finally, the Find thirty. It’s Not a Big Exercise campaign and the new campaign had some similar campaign elements, which may have resulted in an artificial increase in recall and/or recognition of the campaign of interest at baseline (XS1). Although the follow-up campaigns are common, necessary, and ideal, they can also make it difficult to detect effects at subsequent waves.

sec.title: Future Research
sec.p: The use of new technologies such as social media and websites has rapidly grown in the last 5 years and shapes how we communicate today (Chou, Hunt, Beckjor, Moser, & Hesse, 2009; Lefebvre, 2009; Thackeray, Neiger, Hanson, & McKenzie, 2008). This has important implications for future design and delivery of mass media physical activity campaigns (Bauman & Chau, 2009). The literature highlights successful social media strategies used in other health areas, namely, smoking cessation and weight reduction (Chou et al., 2009; Thackeray et al., 2008; Vance, Howe, & Dellavalle, 2009). We suggest new technologies and social media tools may become an integral and important consideration for future physical activity campaign design and delivery.

In conclusion, the Find Thirty every day® campaign resulted in an increase in awareness, intention, and increased levels of walking, vigorous intensity activity, and total physical activity in priority target groups. Campaign effects should be examined by subgroups to identify the most receptive population segments. Elements of the media mix are critical to the effectiveness of mass media campaigns and should be carefully considered. In addition, the changing media landscape and particularly the doubling of free-to-air TV channels may be challenges for future campaign planners. Finally, mass media alone may be insufficient to effect sustained behavioral change across the population. This evaluation highlights that community-wide programs, environmental supports, and advocacy for policy need to work together with mass media to bring about sustained, long-term physical activity behavior change.

fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interests with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.
